document_1: Symbols in chemical equation mean: - (i) › - Gas evolved - (ii) ﬂ - precipitate formed - (iii) (s) - solid state - (iv) (l) - liquid state - (v) (g) - gaseous state - (vi) (aq) - aqueous solution D
document_2: Symbols in chemical equations mean: i) ↑ - Gas evolved ii) ↓ - Precipitate formed iii) - (s) - Solid state iv) (l) - Liquid state v) (g) - Gaseous state vi) (aq) - Aqueous solution

document_1: Valency of nitrogen in: - 1) NO: +2 - 2) N n O: +1 - 3) NO n : +4
document_2: Valency of nitrogen in: i) NO: +2 ii) N ₂ O: +1 iii) NO ₂ : +4 Additional Questions

document_1: Examples of chemical equations: (a) One product : 2H2 + O2 ﬁ 2H2O - (b) Two product : CaCO3 (b) Two product : CaCO3 ﬁ CaO + CO2 (c) Three Products : 4HNO3 ﬁ 2H2O + 4NO2 + O2 - (d) four Products : 2KClO3 (d) four Products : 2KClO3 ﬁ 2KCl + 2O2 + O2 +
document_2: Examples of chemical equations: a) One product: 2H ₂ + O ₂ → 2H ₂ O b) Two ₃ → CaO + CO ₂ c) Three products: 4HNO ₃ → 2H ₂ O + 4NO ₂ + O ₂ d) Four products: 2KClO → 2KCl + 2O ₂ + O ₂ + Heat products: CaCO products: 2KClO ₃

document_1: Three symbols whose first letter is the symbol for them: - (1) Boron (B) - (2) Carbon (C) - (3) Hydrogen (H) ## Page 2
document_2: a) Three metals whose symbols are derived from first letter of their name: - ● Boron (B) - ● Carbon (C) - ● Potassium (K) b) Three metals whose symbols are derived from Latin names: - ● Gold (Au from Aurum) - ● Silver (Ag from Argentum) - ● Iron (Fe from Ferrum)

document_1: The eight metals showing variable valency: ``` 1) Iron (Fe) : +2, +3 2) Copper (Cu) : +1, +2 3) Mercury (Hg) : +1, +2 4) Tin (Sn) : +2, +4 5) Lead (Pb) : +2, +4 6) Gold (Au) : +1, +3 7) Chromium (Cr) : +2, +3, +6 8) Manganese (Mn) : +2, +3, +4, +6, +7 ```
document_2: Eight metals showing variable valency: - 1. Iron (Fe): +2, +3 - 2. Copper (Cu): +1, +2 - 3. Mercury (Hg): +1, +2 - 4. Tin (Sn): +2, +4 - 5. Lead (Pb): +2, +4 - 6. Gold (Au): +1, +3 - 7. Chromium (Cr): +2, +3, +6 - 8. Manganese (Mn): +2, +3, +4, +6, +7 Valency of sulphur in: a) SO ₂ : +4 b) SO ₃ : +6

document_1: If XCl n then X should be a metal with valency 2. Sulphate Formula: XSO n Hydroxide Formula: X(OH) n
document_2: If XCl ₂ is the chloride, then metal X has valency 2. Therefore: - ● Sulphate formula: XSO ₄ - ● Hydroxide formula: X(OH) ₂

document_1: XN is nitride. X is a valency 3 metal as nitrogen has valency 3. Therefore, Sulphate's formula would be X n (SO n ) n and Hydroxide's formula would be X(OH) n
document_2: If XN is the nitride, metal X has valency 3 (since nitrogen has valency 3). Therefore: i) Sulphate formula: X ₂ (SO ₄ ) ₃ ii) Hydroxide formula: X(OH) ₃
